title: FTSE 100 leaps up as traders 'bargain hunt' while Chinese markets stay closed
text:
FTSE 100 leaps up as traders 'bargain hunt' while Chinese markets stay closed FTSE 100 leaps up as traders 'bargain hunt' while Chinese markets stay closed BRITAIN's leading share index shot up in opening trading this morning, as fears over China were temporarily put on ice with markets in the country closed for a holiday. PUBLISHED: 10:26, Thu, Sep 3, 2015 | UPDATED: 11:09, Thu, Sep 3, 2015 GETTY The FTSE staged a recovery in Thursday's trading 
The FTSE 100 jumped up 1.7 per cent in morning trading to sit at around 6,188. 
Investors have been on tenterhooks over the past few weeks over China's stock market crash and slowing economy. 
However, stock markets in Asian country are now closed for a three-day holiday, providing a welcome opportunity for markets in Europe and the US to rally. 
One expert described today's respite from Chinese turmoil as "euphoria" for Europe. Today's increase helps to reverse some of the £50billion losses that the market suffered on Tuesday after a dismal day of trading when the index sank as low as 6028.
The losses were largely prompted by data out of the colossal country that showed that the Chinese manufacturing and services sectors were slowing faster than expected. The Shanghai Composite Index has also suffered huge volatility in recent weeks, which has rubbed off on markets across the world. The index dropped 8.5 per cent in one day alone at the end of August triggering panic in traders across the globe and leading to a huge day of losses now labelled as 'Black Monday'. Related articles The five charts that show exactly why China's economic crisis is... 
In the longer term turmoil is expected to remain, but this week attention will now be on the US, as onlookers try to determine whether the world's largest economy will raise its interest rates in a couple of weeks time. 
David Madden, market analyst at IG, said: "European equity markets are racing higher as traders rejoice in the closure of the Chinese markets. 
"Previously, dealers have been cautious about bargain hunting after many had their fingers burnt, but with China closed until next week traders are taking advantage while they can. 
"China has been the single biggest source of uncertainty in the financial markets in the past few weeks, and for the next two trading sessions that uncertainty has been removed. "Any buying these days tends to be short-lived, and as China isn’t out of the woods yet it will be a true test of confidence to see how long the gains are held." Related articles
